noun.description: The action of pressing; pressure; an instance of this.

In Cartesian physics: pressure or impulse communicated to or propagated through a medium without imparting motion to the particles of the medium, formerly thought to be a possible mechanism for the transmission of light. Now historical.

origin: Mid 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Wyatt (c1503–1542), poet and ambassador. From classical Latin pressiōn-, pressiō pressure from press-, past participial stem of premere to press + -iō.
